Accessibility.html:
Overview

Write some general guidelines around the accessibility of the component. These could be principles for usage, the accessibility goal of the component, or some tips.
Place any pertinent WCAG references here as well.
Example:‚Ä®‚ÄùIt is also important to avoid designing alerts that disappear automatically. An alert that disappears too quickly can lead to failure to meet WCAG 2.0 success criterion 2.2.3.‚Äù
Check out W3C for a quick idea on potential WCAG 2.0 references.
Also, check out Control Hub‚Äôs Accessibility Specs and leverage any content there.

Resources

W3C Patterns

Example

If necessary, show an example of the component with the guidance that you‚Äôre showcasing in the general information above. You could show an example of proper WCAG adherence or a proper interaction pattern.

Color Contrast

Give specific details on some of the requirements of color contrast for this specific component. WCAG References‚Ä®1.4.3: Contrast (Minimum) (Level AA)‚Ä®1.4.11: Non-text Contrast (Level AA)

Spec.html:
Anatomy

This should contain an annotated component in its rest state outlying all the various parts of the component. Follow it with a table that contains the tokens that the component uses in its default rest state. Show more than just color tokens if applicable.
If the component is complex (ie a combination of multiple components), make sure to indicate which other components are being used.

Default token values

Layout

Layout the component and annotate it with annotation markers denoting size and spacing. Also show what options of the component are optional.

*Drag component is 50% opacity of Rest component

Sizing

There is only one size, Default.
*Note: Height (24px) is default size, and depending on the design, width can change depending on radio button label text length.
‚Ä®Border Radius
Checkbox box border radius: 2px

Spacing

Horizontal spacing in label row: 8px
Vertical spacing between label row and help text: 2px

*Drag component is 50% opacity of Rest component

Tokens

Outline all tokens of the component (if available) visually. Follow the visual outline of all components with a table that breaks down all component states into token values.

Color
